Their overindulgence have lead many wretched into insanity, with some forgetting their names entirely. Others simply choose to take one a new one, casting aside any remnants of their old identity.

The wretched use the same naming conventions as high and blood elves, but opt for descriptive and often profound titles in place of typical elven surnames — such as {@i the Reckless} or {@i the Hungerer}.

entries.name: Magic Absorption
entries: Wretched have an insatiable craving for magic and will go to extreme lengths to obtain and consume it. Some wretched are able to devour the essence of a magic item and be empowered by it.
{@note List of Wretched}

entries.name: Leper Gnome
entries: Beneath the snow capped mountains of Dun Morogh lay the halls of Gnomeregan. Once the gnomish capitol, the city's irradiated halls now only swarm with troggs and crazed, addled gnomes. These gnomes, permeating with radiation, have become known as leper gnomes. Their skin has turned a sickly green, dotted with abscesses that burst at the smallest stress or strain.

entries.name: A Necessary Sacrifice
entries: When the gnomish capitol of Gnomeregan was invaded by troggs, a desperate decision was made when the High Tinker ordered all radioactive waste from the city's numerous machines unleashed.

Vented through the city in a noxious green gas, and flooded through the pipes in rivers of green goop, the attempt to cull their invaders ultimately killed off more gnomes than troggs -- and left the city a radioactive wasteland, riddled with danger.
Worse yet, as the city's ruins were later explored, it became clear how many had survived the ordeal; all of them mutated and driven mad by the city's green haze.

entries.name: Hostile Insanity
entries: Fractious at best, the leper gnomes have continued their life in Gnomeregan as though all is as it once was. Their minds warped by toxic fumes, most leper gnomes do not seem to grasp the reality of their situation. Most dangerous are the few that do.

Still sharing the city with their trogg invaders, leper gnomes are known to be extremely paranoid and prone to immediate hostility toward any who would come looking for them. After all, anyone they don't know could suddenly turn out to be in tow with the troggs.

entries.name: Mutated Creatures
entries: Once the radiation takes hold in a creature, as witnessed with the leper gnomes, it slowly warps into something else; gradually tearing it apart until little more is left than a mindless puddle of toxic sludge. With the time the leper gnomes have spent below the earth, in Gnomeregan, some unfortunate few have already twisted and devolved into monstrous aberrations.
{@note List of Leper Gnomes}
The naga are former Highborne night elves, transformed into a race of horrifying sea serpents.

During the Great Sundering, when the Kaldorei city of Zin-Azshari was destroyed, the Kaldorei Queen Azshara and many of her Highborne followers fell into the depths of the Great Sea. Unwilling to face death, Azshara forged a pact with an Old God, N'Zoth, which saw her and her followers twisted into serpentine aberrations.

Most naga who remain belong to either of two groups: those who followed the betrayer, Illidan Stormrage, to find a new home on the shattered world of Outland; and those still loyal to Queen Azshara and her plan to reclaim the surface of Azeroth.

entries.name: Mystical Culture
entries: Naga culture is a complex, multifaceted affair. The distinction between male and female naga saturates everything from their appearance to their perceived place in society.

Male naga are large and muscular creatures, some of them growing to be veritable behemoths with the strength to tear down walls with their bare hands. Most serve as soldiers and guardians, while some hold power as cruel taskmasters or as warlords on the battlefield.

Female naga are more delicate, though ruthlessly cunning and intellectually superior. They are natural spellcasters, and hone their skills to perfection in order to sunder their foes. Naga society is inherently matriarchal, favouring female leaders in zealous homage to their Highborne queen.

entries.name: Azshara's Followers
entries: The naga revere their Queen, the mighty Azshara. To them, she is a living demigod in both power and stature, and all they do is by her design.

Factions of naga work tirelessly in their bid for power, seeking the Queen's blessing. To this end, there are few limits to how far they will go to earn her favour -- even at the cost of their own lives.

entries.name: Naga Myrmidon
entries: The myrmidons, with their navy blue skin and fearsome tridents, are among the strongest among naga warriors. They are feared by all who dwell near the sea; though most prominently by the makrura.
They are often the most fanatical in their loyalty to the Queen. So much so that some would never take to their orders with anything other than utmost obedience.

entries.name: Naga Siren
entries: Naga sirens are female naga who possess potent arcane spellcasting, capable of incapacitating their foes. While not as physical strong as their myrmidon, they are just as fearsome.
Many gather to sing and practice their arcane arts at the Shrines of Azshara, perfecting and improving their insidious craft.

entries.name: Naga War Lord
entries: Naga war lords are male naga warriors with shells and stone-like carapace fused to their skin, entirely covering their head and most of their upper body.
Their right arm has taken on the appearance of a large hermit crab, though it is unknown whether this is an inherent mutation or a deliberate choice.

entries.name: Naga Brute
entries: Naga brutes are massive, lumbering beasts, strong enough to stand as siege weapons for the naga army. Some carry rank and title, while others act like little more than beasts.

Whichever is the case for a particular brute, they are not avoid of intelligence. They follow given orders to the best of their abilities, and know well enough to strategize their way around an obvious trap when they see one.

entries.name: Naga Names and Languages
entries: In addition to speaking Common, the Naga have derived their own language from their Kaldorei roots -- Nazja.
Since the time of the Great Sundering, the language has grown to a distinctly sharp, wheezing character; well-suited for keeping conversation under the sea.

entries.name: Male Names:
entries: Atoph, Drazj, Heth'jatar, Kriellith, Nazjak, Naz'jaran, Skesessh, Zan'zarak

entries.name: Female Names:
entries: Athiasa, Asrasi, Chazjia, Fyashi, Kazsi, Scyalla, Najesha, Zhiasi

entries.name: Tribe Names:
entries: Bloodstrike, Darksquall, Murkwail, Stormbow, Slitherfin, Stormscale, Wrathtail

entries.name: Naga Sorceress
entries: Female naga are primarily spellcasters, and considerably powerful ones at that for how they wield the turbulent powers of the sea. Naga sorceresses are novice spellcasters, as apprentices of a sea witches and sirens.
{@note List of Nagas}

Ogres are large, brutish humanoids of immense strength. Though native to the crumbling world of Draenor, many ogres have since settled as independent clans on Azeroth. The average adult ogre stands between 9 and 10 feet tall, weighing in at almost a thousand pounds.
As far as the ogre is concerned, size is paramount. They eschew any attempt to cover themselves up, keeping their clothing simple, while brandishing fearsome warpaints.

entries.name: Distant Settlements
entries: Following the Horde's second failure to invade Azeroth, the ogre clans that had come with them from Draenor quickly dispersed.

Each clean headed in their own direction. Some sought to return back home, while most were content to stake a claim in this new world. Since then, ogres have settled across the world; from the hills of Arathi and the Cape of Stranglethorn, to the lush reaches of Feralas.

entries.name: Clan Culture
entries: Within ogre clans, it is the strongest that stand in highest regard. An immense show of force is the fastest way to rise, though also the fastest way to fall at the hands of any enemies made along the way.

Still, for as highly as the ogres regard their strength, the powerful and keen-minded ogre magi are often the real presence of power within their clan. Whether acting as the right hand of an ogre lord, or as the clan leader directly, they are the ones pulling the strings.

entries.name: Brutish Combatants
entries: For an ogre, the best solution is often the simplest one. When engaged in a fight, it is not uncommon for the ogre to risk even deadly harm if thinks it can push through and come out on top by sheer virtue of strength.
They are vicious opponents, strong enough to rend limb from limb with their bare hands, and crush skulls with their spiked clubs and stone-hewn mauls.
{@note List of Ogres}

entries.name: Ogre Magi
entries: The ogre magi, with its two heads, holds an intelligence far exceeding the rest of its kin. Borne of the same magic that they wield, it was not uncommon for the Horde -- in its second invasion of Azeroth -- to force this transformation in order to bolster its rank of spellcasters.
Although the two heads are not always in agreement, they are paramount to the ogre's magical aptitude. A living proof that having two heads can be better than having one.

entries.name: Ogre Lord
entries: Ogre lords are massive, hulking figures, towering above their clan in both size and status. While they have no aptitude for magic and little thought for intricate plans, their imposing presence precedes them well enough to keep the rest of their clan in check.
Many might try to challenge an ogre lord's power over the course of its heavy-handed rule, though for most of them this confrontation doesn't end well.

entries.name: Ogre Names and Languages
entries: Historically, ogres have long held their own tongue, though their dispersion across Azeroth have turned many clans to broken forms of Common -- and sometimes Orcish.
Ogre is a very coarse language, largely consisting of short, throaty sounds. Its written form has long been kept solely to the upper echelons of ogre society.
For many ogres, the closest remnant of their language is in their names. Some ogres carry simple, descriptive titles for names, though many still use names with clear meaning in their own tongue.

Most prominent are the names of the {@b ogre magi}. Their two heads have each a mind of their own, and with it their own name. The full name of the magi is a combination of the two: the smartest head first and the other thereafter.

entries.name: Male Names:
entries: Chokk, Drak, Garg, Hok'kran, Krol, Mug

entries.name: Female Names:
entries: Agra, Baki, Brakka, Nakki, Mruka, Ugra'ka

entries.name: Tribe Names:
entries: Bloodcrush, Boulderfist, Dustgorge, Splinterstone, Stonemaul, Warmaul

entries.name: Ogre Priest
entries: A few ogre magi supplement their dark powers with healing spells to aid their allies. They are regarded as spiritual leaders and record-keepers for their tribe.

An ancient curse borne by a highborne sorcerer brought forth the first satyr -- and with it, others would soon follow. These demonic beings were once night elves of the Kaldorei Empire, but little of that heritage remains in their twisted forms. Now there is only anger and hatred.

entries.name: Cursed Affliction
entries: During the War of the Ancients, the Highborne sorcerer Xavius was tasked with opening a portal that would connect Azeroth to the Twisting Nether. His failture to do so brought upon him the wrath of Sargeras, who tore him asunder and tortured his spirit.
As pain and anguish shattered Xavius' mind, the Lord of the Burning Legion still saw use in the sorcerer; and set to forge a new, demonic form for his servant.

In the form of a satyr, Xavius was sent back to Azeroth to spread his curse through the Kaldorei Empire. Like himself, all who he affected were turned to misshapen beasts, capable of pasing their curse onto others in turn. Scores of night elves, and some other races as well, fell to Xavius' dark influence.

entries.name: Created, Not Born
entries: Although both male and female satyrs exist, they have never been able to reproduce. All satyrs in existence were formed from their affliction, some thousands of years old. Though the ages have made them rare, they still pose an imminent threat to any unfortunate enough to encounter them.

entries.name: Burning Hatred
entries: Satyrs are creatures of malice; their veins run a smoldering red as the anguish visited on Xavius is bestowed upon them in turn. They find an indescribable glee in visiting their pain upon others, beast or humanoid -- though none as much as their old elven kin.
Should a satyr cross paths with an outsider, it is not unlikely for it to try and manipulate them, even corrupt them if possible.

entries.name: Tainted Magic
entries: Wherever the satyrs walk, their demonic presence slowly seeps magic from the land. Life withers away, as if touched by the fel itself, while the satyr drains its power for its own nefarous needs.

All the power they drain is stored in their hooves. A peprceptive traveller may be able to distinguish the weak from the strong among satyrs, solely by examining its step -- as if the ground has been scorched by brimstone.

entries.name: Frightful Fighters
entries: Satyrs are not known for forming organized armies with strategies or plans. They live in small and remote sects, tending to their sinister schemes.
When a sentry sounds the alarm, every satyr is quick to join into the fray without any care for their own life. They act like a true horde of demons; one with no commander, and no orders to follow.
{@note List of Satyr}

entries.name: Satyr Trickster
entries: Certain satyrs show a penchant for laying painful traps and ambushing their targets. These tricksters revere and mimic their Lord, Xavius, for his sinister deeds. When the call to battle sounds, they take the subtle approach -- by sneaking up on their enemies to pick off any target they can waylay.

entries.name: Satyr Hellcaller
entries: Satyrs who revel in the arts of fel and shadow magic alike, are known as hellcallers. These warlocks are by far more imposing than the common satyr, as their thirst for magic has bolstered their form just as much as it has tempered their apetite for destruction.

Trolls have made their mark upon the world over milennia, as ancient divides among their kin have brought forth a wide foray of tribes. Today, trolls can be found far and wide across Azeroth, each tribe unuque in its own appearance, customs, and way of life.

entries.name: Rulers of the Ancient World
entries: When the world was still one, before the Great Sundering, the troll race flourished under the rule of the powerful Zandalari empire; able to match even the mighty Mogu dynasti.

The Zandalari relied heavily on its intricate caste system, under which each troll had its given place in life. As time went on, many of these castes grew into a people of their own, parting from the Zandalari to cut their own path in life. From this, two other empires grew forth to rival the Zandalari -- the Amani and the Gurubashi.

Other, smaller tribes tried to escape conflict by settling farther away, though many were made to heel by the three empires. Although animosity between the three was great, Azeroth had a host of other threats that would often draw a common enemy between them.

entries.name: Progenitors of the Elves
entries: Eventually, a colony of dark trolls split free from the Amani empire, ventured forth discover the heart of the continent -- and with it, the cosmic Well of Eternity. By the influence of the well, they were transformed into the Kaldorei, night elves.
At the base of the well, they forged for themselves a new empire. One with which they systematically dismantled the trolls around them, leaving once great empires in ruin.

Ultimately, however, the elves' reckless use of magic lured the demonic Burning Legion to the world. With it, the War of the Ancients began, by the end of which the Well of Eternity imploded in a shockwave that shattered the land and split the continents as they have been ever since.
Great chunks of the remaining Amani and Gurubashi empires were lost, but plenty of land remained for the trolls to rebuild their  cities and reclaim their territories.

entries.name: Racial Differences
entries: The troll race is considered one of the most numerous, yet thoroughly divided. As each tribe has split its own course and claimed its own land, a troll's appearance can alone tell who they are.

entries.name: Tribal Devotion
entries: Trolls have always been a tribal race, isolating themselves and starting anew. A troll’s tribe is its family, and many will go to extreme lengths to protect it as such. They owe loyalty to no-one but their own.

entries.name: Outside Hostility
entries: Trolls settle in remote and isolated areas, places where they can stake their claim and turn the land into their own. The ferocity with which they defend their borders is legendary, to say the least, as they will retaliate swiftly and with force if threatened.

entries.name: Loa's Guidance
entries: Loa is the name trolls have given their animalistic spirit gods. Countless Loa exist, many of them weak and shapeless beings that only trolls can sense, while others take the form of majestic animals. Most troll tribes and empires have their own Loas, manifested as though given shape by the trolls in their worship.

entries.name: Regeneration
entries: Smashing a troll's bones and slashing through its rubbery hide will only serve to anger it, as a troll's wounds close at an extraordinary speed. Only through acid or fire can one arrest their regeneration.
The ability for trolls to regenerate themselves is nothing short of legendary. It can only restore so much, however; as once a troll heart pumps its last, there is no natural way for it to recover.
Oh my - as I suspected. Your ancestry dates back to the dawn of the world. Great were the ancient empires of the trolls. I see a spark in your eyes, a powerful will - you wish to be great again, yes?
{@note List of Trolls}

entries.name: Troll Berserker
entries: To survive a tribe, one must be powerful. For a troll, being powerful means being stronger than one's enemy.

Berserkers are the embodiment of this; with their brutish strength, they hurl their weapons at their targets as they cry for blood. Fearless, they hurl themselves into the fray to attack with reckless abandon.

entries.name: Troll Headhunter
entries: Headhunters are the trackers and hunters of a tribe, using a combination of spear and bolas to bring down their prey.

They make formidable fighters, keen to take trophies from their fallen opponent to display as adornments. These trophies are usually severed fingers or ears, as well as the odd trinket that their quarry might have worn.

entries.name: Troll Witch Doctor
entries: A troll witch doctor holds status as a spiritual leader for its tribe, often acting as a close advisor to its chieftain. They are the eyes that see things which others cannot, and the ones who commune with the Loas on behalf of the tribe.

As cunning as they are intelligent, the wield great magical prowess in their practice of voodoo and alchemy. They know few limits for creating magical concoctions, both to cure ailments and to spur horrors.

entries.name: Dire Troll
entries: These enormous trolls tower above the rest of their kin, as they wield their immense strength to hurl boulders and enemies alike through the air, as well as to pummel them into the ground with almost bestial ferocity.

There is no definitive way to say what stands behind a dire troll's immense stature. Some are elevated through magical or alchemical means, while others have simply evolved to stand larger than life. Whatever the case might be, they are revered as proud and honorable souls among the trolls.

entries.name: Dire Troll Caster
entries: Some dire trolls possess innate magical powers in their blood. These trolls are known as {@i Warcasters}, or {@i Warmothers} if the troll in question is female.

entries.name: Feral
entries: The curse of the worgen can transform even the most civilized person into a ravenous, primal beast. Filled with rage, it gradually loses all vestiges of its former life, as it slowly turns into a mindless hunter. These feral beings bear a closer semblence to monstrous wolves than to intelligent humanoids. However, upon a closer inspection, their eyes betray the mind still trapped within.

entries.name: Ancient Curse
entries: The worgen curse began with a sect of night elves, who tried to tame the powers of the ancient Godrinn. Instead, they were transformed into feral beasts, and subsequently locked away in the Emerald Dream. They were alter brought forth by the Archmage Arugal -- who himself sought a weapon against the Scourge.
Though the worgen were successful in keeping the damned at bay, they did not differ between the living and dead; leaving the curse to quickly seep through Gilneas.

entries.name: Pack Animals
entries: Feral worgen have but a shred of humanity left, locked away in a beast that cannot be reasoned or communicated with. Like wolves, they keep to forested areas and gather  in large packs, headed by their strongest -- the alpha.

entries.name: Humanoid Cubs
entries: Worgen do not give birth to lupine humanoids, but rather to a humanoid of their original race. Although the mother might care for its child, this is often not shared by the rest of its pack.

entries.name: Resistance to Undeath
entries: The curse of the worgen draws its power from the Emerald Dream, and the light of the goddess Elune. For this, raising a worgen into undeath is by far more difficult than it is with most other humanoids.

entries.name: Feral Weaknesses
entries: As vicious as they are, these feral beasts are hardly intimidated and rarely back down if the pack keeps together. They do, however, have a strong dislike for open fires, and avoid areas lit by open flames whenever possible -- so long as the hunger for flesh does not force them to push through.

They also appear to be very susceptible to the wolfsbane plant; a small, purple flower commonly found across the kingdom of Gilneas. If this seemingly harmless plant comes in contact with a worgen's wounds, it prevents the beast from recuperating.

entries.name: Player Characters as Feral Worgen
entries: A humanoid bit by a worgen must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or be cursed. The curse has no effect on undead beings, such as the forsaken. A character bit begins to show the effects of the curse after 1d4 days, at which point the character is transformed into a feral worgen. It gains a Strength of 15 if their score isn't already higher, and their alignment changes to Chaotic Evil.
The cursed character also gains the following indefinite madness, {@i "I hunger for the taste of blood and will kill anyone to taste it once more."}

The character remains a feral worgen until a {@spell greater restoration} spell or more powerful magic rids the character of their indefinite madness, at which point alignment returns to what it was before being bit, and the character gains the {@i Two Forms} feature and the {@i Worgen Form Traits} of the Worgen race.
{@note List of Worgen}

data.name: Plant Creatures
entries: {@b Plants} in this context are vegetable creatures, not ordinary flora. Most of them are ambulatory, and some are carnivorous. The quintessential plants are the ancients and treants. Fungal creatures such as sporelings and the mandragora also fall into this category.

entries.name: Ancients
entries: The Ancients are massive, leaf-covered trees given life. With an unparalleled wisdom and insight into the world around them, they act asguardians of the forests where they dwell -- such as those of northern Kalimdor, where their shared bonds with the night elves have kept the two races in a long-lasting symbiosis.

entries.name: Staunch Defenders.
entries: An ancient is grown from an acorn, like so many other trees, though the acorn itself is far rarer and far more powerful. It takes years upon years for an ancient to grow to its full size, where it stays for thousands of years without feeling the wear of old age.

The ancients who have allied themselves with the honorable night elves stand guard of their cities, and of their border territories. They can burrow their rooted feet into the soil beneath, becoming indistinguishable from a normal tree if they stand perfectly still. This allows both for other creatures to take shelter between its leaves, such as a squirrel with its own acorns, and for the ancient to keep quiet watch over the wilds.
Due to their immense lifespan and often slow, lumbering presence, an ancient sees time differently from mortal races. Often times, years may become akin to hours, minutes, or even seconds.

entries.name: Plantlike Creatures
entries: An ancient doesn't require food or sleep. Instead, it draws nourishment from the soil and can carry on for weeks without a fresh supply of water.

entries.name: Ancient Protector
entries: Most often when the acorn of an ancient sprouts, it grows to become an ancient protector. These hulking trees make up most of the ancients, and are critical in safeguarding night elven civic areas and groves.

entries.name: Ancient of Lore
entries: Some ancients grow to become enlightened beings of the forest, wise beyond belief and capable of establishing meaningful contact with the free-spirited dryads. These ancient have a close connection to night elven druids and priests, taking on a role as instructors in the ways of magic and the secrets of nature.

entries.name: Ancient of War
entries: The toughest of ancients grow into ancients of war; mighty plants often found defending night elven settlements or supporting Alliance forces in battle. Embodied in these ancient guardians are the spirits of courage and determination, which they wield to call upon the forest itself to rise in order to turn the tide of battle in favour of them and their allies.

entries.name: Tree of Life
entries: A tree of life is a sapling born from the world tree Nordrassil, these ancients have suffered great losses in recent wars, and those who remain have returned to the forest to spread their seeds and replenish their numbers undisturbed.
A tree of life has a challenge rating of 10 (5,900 XP). It has the same statistics as an ancient of lore, and gains the following additional traits:

entries.name: Nature's Blessing.
entries: The tree add its Wisdom modifier to its Armor Class (AC 19).

entries.name: Rooted Tranquility.
entries: While the tree have taken root, each plant of the tree's choice within 60 feet of it regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn. If the plant takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the plant's next turn. A plant dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points.

entries.name: Spellcasting.
entries: The tree has the following additional spells prepared.

items: 4th level: {@i {@spell guardian of nature|xge}, {@spell grasping vine}}

entries: The tree has the following additional action option.

entries.name: Summon {@creature Wisp|WC5E MoM|Wisps} (1/Day).
entries: The tree calls forth ten wisps that appear in empty spaces within 60 feet of it. These wisps act as allies of the tree. The wisps remains for 1 day or until they die.

entries.name: Bog Beasts
entries: A bog beast is a massive, shambling monster made of plants, roots, and flesh. Inhabiting bogs and swamps, they hide away beneath the water surface, disguising themselves as thick, waterlogged lumps of vegetation. There they wait patiently for any unaware critters to venture too close -- or better yet, unaware adventurers.

entries.name: Creatures of Mystery
entries: Bog beasts are frightful creatures, and notoriously elusive. They are adept at avoiding the gaze of scholars attempting to study them; and for many who have tried, only moss-riddled remains have been found. Their aggressive, territorial nature makes them a considerable danger to any unfortunate enough to cross paths with them.

entries.name: Plants Anatomy
entries: Thick roots stretch across the entirety of the bog beast's form, as if to conceal what hides underneath. It is speculated that they have no real need for sustenance apart from the waters they dwell in, and some have been observed spending months still in the murky depths -- only barely grasping the surface to draw breath.

entries.name: Naturally Powerful
entries: Explorers who have encountered a bog beast and lived to tell the tale, describe them as immensely powerful and resilient to harm. Their massive limbs can quickly overwhelm their enemies, crushing opponents with their fists or with whatever nearby objects they can throw.
{@note List of Bog Beasts}

entries.name: Timberling
entries: A timberling is by many considered the child of bog beasts, very similar and yet considerably smaller at a height comparable to that of a dwarf. As far as bog beasts go, timberlings are fairly peaceful creatures that live in harmony with the land. However, any disruption to their habitat will quickly drive them into an unnatural frenzy.

entries.name: Thistleshrub
entries: Thistleshrubs, unlike most bog beasts, do not dwell in swamps or marshes. Instead they prefer arid climates, and bear a resemblance to a large mass of withered vines covered in sharp briars. They are known to be very hostile, and will certainly attack anyone foolish enough to approach; sporadically lashing out with whip-like thorns at anything that comes near.

entries.name: Swampwalker
entries: These hulking masses are rarely ever witnessed outside of dense swamps, and blend perfectly into their chosen habitat with their dark green and brown colors.

They are both the most territorial and the most cunning among bog beasts, and have been witnessed deliberately attempting to lure travellers farther into their lair in order to spring a trap. Their natural camouflage allows them to move through their territory entirely unseen, and have left adventurers wary even of rippling water and rustling leaves when venturing through swamps.

entries.name: Tar Creeper
entries: Cherishing humid air and temperatures, the tar creeper is by far the most abnormal of all bog beasts for its viscous, tar-like appearance. Not to mention the most dangerous.
Though they might seem slow, these massive beasts can cut through tar like a fish through water; lunging forth to trap their prey and drag it back down below.

entries.name: Lashers
entries: Lashers are a family of large, slithering flora, known for their long, appendage-like tendrils and found across most of Azeroth. Though most lashers are not predatory, they will defend themselves if threatened.

entries.name: Sentient Plants
entries: Their existence is the result of nature magic, seeped down into the ground and left to spread. There, it has given the plants enough will to uproot themselves and roam around. For some lashers, this awakening has been deliberate and fairly harmless. For others, it has transformed the plants into vile monstrosities.

entries.name: Widely Adapted
entries: A lasher spitter is a large, carnivorous plant. It produces a strong acid within its stalk, which it then spits out with impressive accuracy through the large maw situated between its petals. The acid is strong enough to dissolve flesh, for easier consumption.

entries.name: Fast Learners
entries: Though they appear driven by little more than instinct, fully mature lashers have shown themselves to be remarkably intelligent. Even capable of laying traps, forming decorations, and conveying messages with simple gestures.
{@note List of Lashers}

entries.name: Lasher Spitter
entries: A lasher spitter is a large, carnivorous plant. It produces a strong acid within its stalk, which it then spits out with impressive accuracy through the large maw situated between its petals. The acid is strong enough to dissolve flesh, for easier consumption.

entries.name: Barbed Orchid
entries: A barbed orchid stands out from other lashers for its large, vibrant flower-head, centre of which some describe as resembling an owlbeast's beak. Their long tendrils are covered with barbs, which they strike out at prey and intruders alike.

entries.name: Bloodpetal Flayer
entries: At a glance, most would take the bloodpetal flayer for little more than a very colorful lasher. Looks are sure to betray, however; as these lashers are unmatched for their ferocity, and for the potency of the vile toxin kept in their sharp thorns.

entries.name: Mature Lasher
entries: When lashers reach maturity, some learn to channel the powers of the moon in their favor.
A mature lashers has the same statistics as a lasher spitter, except that it has a Wisdom score of 12, and replaces the spitter's action options with the following action option:

entries.name: Dream Lash.
entries: {@i Ranged Spell Attack:} +3 to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@i Hit:} 5 (1d10) radiant damage.

entries.name: Rooted Tranquility.
entries: While the tree have taken root, each plant of the tree's choice within 60 feet of it regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn. If the plant takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the plant's next turn. A plant dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points.

entries.name: Spellcasting.
entries: The tree has the following additional spells prepared.

items: 4th level: {@i {@spell guardian of nature|xge}, {@spell grasping vine}}

entries: The tree has the following additional action option.

entries.name: Summon Wisps (1/Day).
entries: The tree calls forth ten wisps that appear in empty spaces within 60 feet of it. These wisps act as allies of the tree. The wisps remains for 1 day or until they die.

entries.name: Treants
entries: Few would gaze upon the stout treants and assume them to be wise or strong, but these awakened trees have been imbued by the spirits of the forests in which they dwell. In times of peace, they act as keepers and tenders. In times of war, they rise to defend their groves with fervor.

entries.name: Saplings of Ancients
entries: The treants begin their lives as sapling sprouds of the ancients, carrying many of the same qualities as the tree from which they came -- be it be it boldness, tenderness, or a great force of will. Like the forest around them, treants never cease to grow. Instead, they rise taller and taller, century by century passing by, until the time is right for one to rise into the annals as an ancient protector.

entries.name: Guardians of Nature
entries: Like the ancients, treants live to serve the forces of nature. Should someone dare to bring harm to their domain, it is they who wander the woods in search the perpetrators. If confronted, the treants respond by slashing wildly with their barbed claws.

Their task of safe-guarding nature have granted them favor among druids and woodland creatures alike. It is rare to see a treant wandering alone, as they are often accompanied by sprouts and other critters.

entries.name: Corrupted and Unpredictable
entries: During the Third War, as the Burning Legion once more invaded Azeroth, numerous forests were set ablaze -- most notably, the forests of Ashenvale and Quel'Thalas.
With the destruction of their groves, the treants who delved within were driven to the brink of insanity, their hollow shells quickly gripped by the Legion's influence.

Though the invasion was since quelled, many groves are still saturated with demonic corruption; the treants within ready to lash out at any who would dare appproach. Adventurers who have taken upon them to visit these ancient sites, have borne witness to withered shambles lurking between dead trees and fallen ruins.

entries.name: Treant Wildcaller
entries: Although all treants can manipulate the forest to some degree, wildcallers can harness the full might of the wilderness. A treant wildcaller has a challenge rating of 3 (700 XP). It has 45 (7d8 + 14) hit points and the following trait.

entries.name: Spellcasting.
entries: The treant is a 4th-level spellcaster. its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (save DC 11, +3 to hit with spell attacks). The treant has the following druid spells prepared:

items: Cantrips (at will): {@i {@spell druidcraft}, {@spell solar wrath|WC5E Spells}, {@spell thorn whip}}
1st level (4 slots): {@i {@spell cure wounds}, {@spell faerie fire}, {@spell sleep}}

entries: {@note List of Treants}

data.name: [PH] The Emerald Dream
entries: [PH]

entries.name: [PH]
entries: [PH]
{@note Denizens of the Dream}

entries.name: [PH] Dryads
entries: [PH]

entries.name: Daughter of Cenarius
entries: [PH] Some dryads inherit druidic powers from their father, Cenarius, allowing them to protect and heal their allies.

entries.name: [PH] Faerie Dragon
entries: Some ancients grow to become enlightened beings of the forest, wise beyond belief and capable of establishing meaningful contact with the free-spirited dryads. These ancient have a close connection to night elven druids and priests, taking on a role as instructors in the ways of magic and the secrets of nature.

entries.name: Tiny Fearie Dragons
entries: Many faerie dragons are naturally very small in size and usually harmless if encountered alone, while quite dangerous if someone face them in groups.

entries.name: [PH] Keeper of the Grove
entries: The toughest of ancients grow into ancients of war; mighty plants often found defending night elven settlements or supporting Alliance forces in battle. Embodied in these ancient guardians are the spirits of courage and determination, which they wield to call upon the forest itself to rise in order to turn the tide of battle in favour of them and their allies.

data.name: Elemetals & Primordials
entries: [PH] This sections contains cratures who are the manifestation of primal forces such as the elements air, each, fire, and water but also those represent the cosmisc forces such as death and deacay, discorder and fel, light and holy, life and nature, order and arcane, shadow and void.

entries.name: Elementals
entries: Elementals are ageless, ever-changing spirits of the primal forces that forge worlds; volatile beings of raw elemental power, manifested in physical form. The most common primordial form of life has been these elementals, who come before any organic life is ever able to be born, and will persist long after all organic life has perished.

entries.name: Base Primal Forces
entries: The elements are a complex hotbed of different forces and interactions, but for the most part, four primary materials are manifested. These are, of course, fire, water, earth and air; the building blocks of the world.

entries.name: Spiritual Conflict
entries: The fifth element is said to be spirit, the inner energy of all living beings. Worlds with strong spirit are tranquil and manifest few elemental spirits who act in harmony. However, worlds with compromised spirit will result in all-out war that can shatter and recreate the surface of the world multiple times in a day.

entries.name: Bound to the Elemental Plane
entries: On Azeroth, as the titanic Keepers saw to the ordering of the world, they found the elementals wreaking havoc under the corrupting influence of the Old Gods. As a safeguard, the Keepers constructed the Elemental Plane as a prison in which the elemental lords could be locked away. In their absence, the Keepers could tend to their task at hand; settling the natural order of Azeroth.

The Elemental Plane is intimately connected to the world of Azeroth, preventing all but the weakest manifestations of elemental power in the world. It is divided into four interlinked realms: the Abyssal Maw, realm of water; Deepholm, realm of earth; the Firelands, realm of fire; and Skywall, realm of air.

entries.name: Shamanic Allies
entries: Much of the responsibilities of the elements to maintain the balance of the world falls into the hands of the shamans. Shamans commune with them using spiritual magic, borrowing their powers only at the elements' permission. Because of this, shamans are forever devoted to a cycle of favor and thanks, gaining great power in exchange for reverence, loyalty, or whatever other small favors the spirits may seek.

entries.name: Elemental Instability
entries: Even the Titanic prison cannot fully keep the forces of the world locked away, and any place of major elemental significance is likely to have a few minor elementals roaming around. Ancient springs, deep canyons, and especially volcanoes and powerful storms all may spawn elementals.

Similarly, skilled spellcasters can summon more powerful elementals directly from their home plane. An elemental spawned this way will be bound in a pair of bracers, necessarily limiting their power and binding them to the command of whoever summoned them.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: Elementals do not eat, drink or sleep. They do not feel pain, and if they are killed, they will return to their home plane. They will die permanently only if killed while in their home plane.
{@note List of Elementals}

entries.name: Air Elementals
entries: Taking the form of a swirling vortex of air, a collection of clouds and static, or even an almost humanoid amalgam of storm, frost, or dust, the elementals of air command the realm of the sky. Turbulent gales and gentle breezes tell locals the mood of the element of air, while fierce lightning lashes at whomever may have angered them.

entries.name: Thunderbolts and Lightning
entries: The wrath of storms is among the most catastrophic and impressive shows of pure power within nature. Shamans wielding lightning grasp extraordinary amounts of energy, perhaps more than any other force at their call, and these shamans are careful to wield it with caution.

entries.name: The Four Winds
entries: The world's winds are categorized among the four cardinal directions: North, East, South, and West. Each wind carries with it a different aspect of the weather.

The frigid North Wind carries blizzards, sleet storms and cold snaps; while the swelling East Wind brings with it storm force winds, gales, cyclones and hurricanes. The South Wind carries brutal thunderstorms from the sea, crashing lightning, rain, and clinging static; while  with the West Wind comes gentle breezes, carrying the changing of winter to spring, scented with pollen.

entries.name: Skywall
entries: The realm of air, Skywall, takes the form of astonishing white and gold palaces that stretch into a clear sunny sky, seemingly crafted out of the clouds themselves. Ever buffeted by gentle breezes, the towering jeweled archi- tecture possesses few floors or stairways; the chief mode of travel in the realm of air is free flight, a feature every denizen possesses.

entries.name: Elemental Hierarchy
entries: Sitting atop the the Throne of the Four Winds is Al'Akir the Windlord. Below him are his four lieutenants - the Conclave of Wind - who act as secondary rulers of each of the four winds. Leadership of the four winds is in flux, changing anytime their political foes decide that their time as lords is over. Al'akir, of course, watches the struggles for power with amusement, firm in the knowledge that his own rule is undisputed.

entries.name: Cunning Winds
entries: More than the swirling power of the sky, the element of air is most associated with intellect and cunning. Its elemental masters rule the skies with royal authority, manipulating the complex systems of friend and foe within their own realm in much the same way as a mortal government.

entries.name: Subjects of Skywall
entries: These elemental creatures range widely, from spectres of the faintest squalls to mighty stormclouds given humanoid shape. Fierce elementals in the shape of Azeroth's dragons, known as storm dragons, guard Skywall's paths and bridges, while the spirits of howling gales threaten to blow smaller entities away. In the finest temples stand the djinn, swirling sultans of the winds, acting out the Windlord's highest commands.

entries.name: Earth Elementals
entries: Rumbling boulders, coated in moss or baked red in the sun, pull together as though attracted by gravity. They form the vaguest shape of a torso, misshapen from its rocky components, which begin to gently orbit one another. Tiny pinprick eyes observe the world around it, and do so for hours. What is it thinking as the world goes by?

entries.name: Strength and Stability
entries: The power of the earth is slow yet strong. Despite this quiet strength, no other element is able to cause as much change to the world. Mountains alter weather patterns and deny the movements of living beings merely by their presence, while an earthquake can wipe a city that has lasted a hundred years off the map in mere moments.

entries.name: The Everpatient Mountain
entries: The element of earth has personalities that can embody aspects of the earth such as the intimidating power of mountains or the potential motion of earthquakes and avalanches. Most commonly however, earth is the element of fortitude, patience and steadfastness. While their strength stems from this, it often comes with a weakness in an unwillingness to act, exercising extreme caution in all decisions.

entries.name: Deepholm
entries: Deepholm, Azeroth's plane of earth, is a vast, seemingly endless network of gigantic caverns, winding tunnels and quicksilver lakes. What little that is organic must live without sunlight, for only the dim glow of crystal growths and arcing energy provides illumination. Crystals grow slowly out of ancient structures built for feet that will never walk them, and throughout the realm rocks, islands and tiny articulates drift gently in the air, uninterested in gravity’s distractions.

entries.name: Elemental Hierarchy
entries: The ruler of Deepholme has always been Therazane the Stonemother. Below her are her sons, the immense stone colossi known as the Stone Lords, each embodying a different aspect of the earth in both appearance and personality. While whether or not the Stone Lords are the actual sons of the Stonemother is unknown, their familial bonds result in a very stable system of governance for the earthen plane.

entries.name: Sanctuary of the Black
entries: The black dragonflight, with their connection to the earth and deep places of the world, have been a semi-regular sight in these dark caverns. Deathwing has used the domain of the Stonemother as a sanctuary several times over the last few millenia, recuperating in the powerful energies of the Stonecore after failed clashes with the forces of Azeroth.

entries.name: Holding Up the World
entries: In the center of Deepholm, in the immense Temple of Earth, resides the World Pillar. This artifact of the Titans is the keystone that bears the weight of all the elemental and magnetic forces in the Elemental Plane. Without it, Deepholm and by extension the rest of the plane would collapse into Azeroth, causing untold destruction to both the elementals and the planet. Deathwing's shattering of the stone when he escaped the plane during the Cataclysm has earned the entire black dragonflight the eternal emnity of the earth elementals.

entries.name: Denizens of Deepholm
entries: Earthen spirits come in many forms, in various combinations of rock, crystal, or metal. When the earth is threatened, it will spawn worms of crushing crystal teeth, geode giants coated in shining opals, furious storms of dust, metal-skinned animals, earthen warriors and even stone in the shape of dragons.

entries.name: Dust Devil
entries: A dust devil is an elemental of air and earth. Roaring out across the land, these violent vortexes can spell a real problem for any  nearby settlements, as their chaotic nature makes them prone to cause great upheaval.

entries.name: Eternal Nuisance
entries: Dust devils find an unusual enjoyment in their uncanny roaming, destroying whatever they come across in their path by sending forth incredible gusts of wind or by tearing it asunder with their hands.

entries.name: Conjured by Magic
entries: Certain spells and magic items can conjure forth elementals from the Elemental Plane to the Material Plane. Elementals, and dust devils in particular, resent this treatment and the shackles of servitude that comes with it. A creature that summons an elemental must assert the force of will to control it.

entries.name: Shale Spider
entries: Shale spiders are durable diggers, native to the elemental plane of Deepholm. They possess a tenacity and ferocity not shown in many other elementals; as one will often fight until it is utterly and entirely torn asunder.

entries.name: Stone Nuisance
entries: The spiders sometimes find their way out of Deepholm, emerging onto the surface. A newly emerged shale spider is fairly harmless, keeping reclusive while it tries to adapt to its new environment. Once it has, however, it sets out to hunt -- often with a voracious hunger.

entries.name: Swarmers
entries: Above all, the shale spiders are notorious swarmers. They'll often work together to take down their prey. Sometimes, a single shale spider will pretend to be alone, while its kin lays in wait for an opportunity to strike.

entries.name: Lava Spider
entries: [PH] The lava spider is much like the shale spider but they usually dwel in areas with pools of lava.

entries.name: Fire Elementals
entries: A cruel-eyed face staring out of a body like the smoldering of a furnace freed of its constraints. Overwhelming heat crisps the ground around it, and shimmers the air, even as a fire elemental reaches out, eager to spread the flames of its never-ending rage.

entries.name: Burning Passion
entries: Fire is, in a word, the element of passion. This is a two-sided coin, as spirits of fire are as vulnerable to extreme fits of blinding rage as they are to good humour, though the former is far more common. They are creatures of immediate need, representing both the burning heat that forged the world and the joy and anger of consciousness.

entries.name: Fiery Gifts
entries: More than any other element, the realm of fire has involved itself in the affairs of mortals. This ranges from simple matters such as fire elementals taking part in Summer festivals, to things as complex as whole mountain ranges being ruled by powerful fire lords, or mutations of mortal races into fire elementals.

entries.name: The Firelands
entries: A simple name to elucidate the core of a place; the plane of fire is an endless sky of burning, blazing smog, filled with small islands of volcanic rock. The intense heat is enough to set ablaze anything not of the realm, and water is a thing of fantasy. Rivers of molten lava split the dry rock, while irregular igneous rock grows and cools into grand shapes, ever changing the landscape.

entries.name: Elemental Hierarchy
entries: Ruling from the Sulfuron Keep is Ragnaros the Firelord, with the second in command being his Majordomo. Below them are the various Lords and Barons of the Firelands. A lord's rank is determined by his martial prowess, as to gain and hold your position you must be capable of defeating all who would contest your power.

entries.name: Lords of Cinder
entries: The Firelands are a militant place, kept under a strict hierarchy of command with ascension in rank coming exclusively through rite of succession; the fiery lieutenants of the Firelord have for eons remained in charge by holding off competitors at every turn. There is no subtlety in the Firelands, and combat is determined quickly, and to the bitter end, inevitably resulting in a group of lords that is both ancient, and unrelenting.

entries.name: Ruler of Blackrock
entries: Long ago, Ragnaros was summoned by the Dark Iron dwarves as part of their war against their Bronzebeard and Wildhammer kinsmen. His arrival shattered the Redridge Mountains, created the Burning Steppes and Searing Gorge, and turned Blackrock Mountain into an active volcano. The surviving Dark Iron dwarves were enslaved by the Firelord and his lieutenants, acting as his tools for hundreds of years while he gathered his strength in the Molten Core, awaiting the time he could burn all of Azeroth to ash.

entries.name: Forces of the Firelands
entries: Empty fields of cracked ground are patrolled by its denizens, including by far the largest amount of fleshy creatures of any elemental plane; molten magma giants, two-headed core hounds, serpentine flamewakers and their skeletal hound pets. Huge worms swim and hunt in the magma rivers, while beautiful giant fire hawks blaze across the sky.

entries.name: Core Hounds
entries: Core Hounds are a monstrous, vicious, two-headed bulldogs with a faithful bond to the Firelord Ragnaros and his minions. Waves of scorching heat emanate from an core hound's body, and those who engage with them head-on quickly find their weapons rendered useless as each slash and stab melts it all away.

They are are ferocious, unforgivable beings. Hostility toward intruders is always a given, as they are impossible to reason with. They take orders solely from the Firelord's rank and file, or from the Firelord himself.
Their body is covered in thick, sweltering metal plates, with streaks of fire running the length of its back. Its mouth is filled with rows of sharp teeth, said to be hotter than white-hot steel.

entries.name: Faithful Servants
entries: Core hounds are the faithful servants of the Firelord and his minions, and in many ways do act like loyal dogs in that regard, following the will of their fiery master as best they can.

entries.name: Endless Growth
entries: If allowed, a core hound can grow for an eternity, ultimately becoming hulking titans of gargantuan size -- like their progenitor, Magmadar. Few core hounds ever manage to reach such a size, as often their aggressive nature becomes their downfall.
The dark iron hounds, considered misshapen by true core hounds, cease to grow once they reach maturity.

entries.name: Core Guardians
entries: Most who venture to Blackrock Mountain would rather face a squad of orcs than confront a single core hound. These hulking bulldogs drip of magma as they trail, guarding the molten core of the black mountain -- as well as the scorched earth of the lands around.

entries.name: Water Elementals
entries: Amorphous masses of pure spring water, bound in bracers. Floating shards of ice the size of a man, glaring with cold stares. It is said that water elementals take on the fewest known types of all elementals, but this is untrue; the nature of water is shapelessness. Formless and versatile, water is the free-flowing element of change, and its elementals may take whatever form suits them.

entries.name: Ebb and Flow
entries: Water is the element of change, calm, and healing, but also of crushing depths, biting cold, and secrets hidden so far down that light may never reach them. Water's servants, therefore, channel not only the restorative powers of fresh springs, but also the freezing, lashing, pressing force of deep oceans and frigid ice.

entries.name: A Spring of Calm
entries: Water is seen as the most tranquil of elements, or at least the least volatile. Places significant to it are well known for their healing properties, particularly among shamanistic races. Spirits may similarly manifest in clean rivers, gushing waterfalls, or at the hearts of glaciers, wherever the water is purest. The many seas are the place of water's greatest raw strength, and spirits of the sea are often far more robust. In places of corruption or filth, the elementals will become sickly and aggressive.

entries.name: Abyssal Maw
entries: Unsurprisingly, this plane is almost entirely underwater. It displays examples of all areas of sea life, from the well-lit shallow coral reefs to the lightless abyssal trenches that crisscross the ocean floor. Buildings are half made of carved stone and shells, and half of bubbles and froth, with windows made simply by supporting water vertically.

entries.name: Elemental Hierarchy
entries: The Maw is ruled by Neptulon the Tidehunter, who reigns from the Throne of the Tides. Much like the Firelands, there are a number of lords below him that assist the rule of the Elemental Lord. Unlike the armies of fire, the titles of nobility rarely change hands due to the adaptive nature of the aquatic masters.

entries.name: Elemental Hierarchy
entries: Ruling from the Sulfuron Keep is Ragnaros the Firelord, with the second in command being his Majordomo. Below them are the various Lords and Barons of the Firelands. A lord's rank is determined by his martial prowess, as to gain and hold your position you must be capable of defeating all who would contest your power.

entries.name: Hydraxian Waterlords
entries: While the other elements are content to help only those that appeal to themselves, water flows more freely, and its elementals are historically the most cooperative with mortals, even high-ranking lieutenants of the Tidehunter. On Azeroth, water's servants have actively taken part in the defense of the world on multiple occasions, even as the others remained silent.

entries.name: Masses of the Abyssal Maw
entries: The denizens of the plane of water are far less rigidly categorised than the other planes, owing to water's very nature. Those few who take solid shape at all will still only be vaguely humanoid, though some mortal races are closely associated with the plane, such as the sea giants, murlocs and, of course, millions of species of fish. In many ways, these mortal species show far more than the elements the heart of the element of water, as they are the most versatile sorts across the entire multiverse. The Elemental Lord of Water, Neptulon, represents this by seldom taking a solid form, preferring to exist among his element as raging tides, gentle currents and fatherly flows.

entries.name: Ice Elemental
entries: Manifest from frozen water, ice elementals share domain and allegiance with other water elementals. It moves unhindered through the icy reaches in which it dwells, and is very quick to enrage at the sight of fire wielded in its vicinity.

entries.name: Unclear Origins
entries: Ice elementals are one of the anomalous mysteries of the elemental world. Some shamans say they are simply a rare type of water elemental, frozen in form and associated with water in its solid state. Others claim that some ice elementals are unnatural conglomerate elementals of ice and earth, formed in unknown circumstances, who represent and govern the changing of summer to winter. The truth is unknown, as the only ones with that knowledge - the elementals themselves - are notorious for keeping their secrets close.

entries.name: Scattered Peoples
entries: Unlike other elementals, there are no real homes for these creatures of ice. They tend to be found on their own or in small groups located around mountaintop glaciers or large ice floes. Only in Northrend are there large numbers of ice elementals, due to the eternal winter that grips most of the continent.

entries.name: The Ice Stone has Melted
entries: The master elemental of frost is undoubtedly Ahune, the Frost Lord, a poorly-tempered elemental of immense power. Ahune, easily manipulated, seeks yearly to bring an end to the hated heat of high Summer, and at this time frost elementals will manifest across the globe, seeking to cool it through the creation of vast obelisks of ice. It is a plan doomed to fail, of course, and Ahune's persistence is held at bay on each summer solstice through shamanic ritual.

entries.name: Elemental Revenant
entries: The elemental revenants are yet another long-unsolved mystery among many others out in the frozen land of Northrend. Far up at the cap of the world, these elemental spirits appear to be bound within enormous, ancient sets of rough-hewn armor, drifting along above the ground as though caught in gentle breeze. They are rare and, when seen, often appear to be following some kind of distant, obscure desire to stand guard, following no apparent patterns or goals beyond protecting a single area for centuries at a time.

entries.name: Mysterious Origins
entries: Though they are elemental in nature, these entities are vanishingly rare outside of Northrend, and are not seen in their respective elemental planes. It is yet unknown why they act and appear the way they do, or even if they originated as elementals.

entries.name: Complex Loyalties
entries: Some of the revenants of Northrend have been seen serving a mysterious master in the mountains, though for what purpose, to what end, and how deep this loyalty lies is unknown.

entries.name: Tundra Ghosts
entries: The revenants that drift across the snow, barely visible through blizzards and mist, have a ghostly, ethereal quality to them, and are believed by some local cultures to be the spirits of dead warriors bound eternally to their armor.
{@note List of Revenants}

entries.name: Air Revenant
entries: Arcing electricity and static clinging to armour or weapons herald the arrival of an air or lightning revenant, twisted ribbons of rough metal wrapped around a powerful vortex. Lightning comes to their aid, wielded like a club, while the currents of air around them whip and tug at their foes. Their voices, shrill shrieks, are that of the most violent of icy gales.

entries.name: Earth Revenant
entries: Plumes of stones and dry earth support stout, sturdy plates roughly riveted together. A massive club, thick enough to topple walls, drifts nearby. An earth revenant wields pure, raw power, roaming their territories slowly, with the assurance that any opposition will be completely flattened.

entries.name: Fire Revenant
entries: Jagged, scaled armor kept red-hot by the blazing flames within, a fire revenant resembles a floating foundry, spewing molten slag and burning coals in its wake. Unlike most revenants, their weapons are well-crafted and often beautiful, albeit hot enough to brand their foes with artful scars. When rarely seen outdoors in Northrend, the extreme heat flowing out of their bodies clashes with the cold and blankets them in steam.

entries.name: Water Revenant
entries: Smooth pots or jugs - connected to a water revenant's armoured body by thick chains - constantly spill out with the clear, freezing water that comprises the vague appearance of a body. Frigid temperatures accompany these revenants, who may well be the most at home in the icy land of Northrend. Water ebbs and flows at their command, frostbite awaits anyone at the receiving end of their jagged, cruel scimitars.

entries.name: Death Revenant
entries: A mystery even greater than the cause of elemental revenants is the death revenants, so seldom seen as to border on mythical. Spoken of in hushed tones, and only when the sun is high, these fell spirits are said to be spirits of death itself. Great black scythes are wielded empty metal husks, who move eerily silent and speak only to the mind. It is unknown if these dread reapers are even of the same ilk as other revenants, and their desires are, once again, a mystery.

entries.name: Primordials
entries: [PH] Some entities much like elementals form out of other primordial forces.
{@note List of Primordials}

entries.name: Arcane Elemental
entries: In the case of places overflowing with arcane power, the energy will manifest arcane elementals, similarly bound by bracers and similarly populated by inscrutable minds that seem to act on the seemingly random nature of the arcane itself.

entries.name: A Mage's Best Servant
entries: As accumulations of arcane energy, arcane elementals can be crafted and bound into service by powerful mages. It is not uncommon to find numerous lesser elementals being used as simple servants in magical academies and cities such as Silvermoon or Dalaran.

entries.name: Arcane Anomalies
entries: Arcane elementals are rare anomalies, and are most commonly seen in places suffused with arcane power. This makes them relatively common at the sites of exposed ley lines, the magical channels that flow under the surface of planets like blood vessels.

entries.name: Ley Lines
entries: Ley lines are channels of immense arcane power that runs all along the surface of a planet in an interconnected web. They are usually buried deep in the earth, visible only to the eyes of those deeply attuned to magic such as the blue dragonflight. Those that are exposed to the surface usually begin to crystallize in the form of glowing purple mana crystals. They have been used for many things, such as creation of moonwells to powering portal spells.

Ley lines form and change based on the locations of their nexuses--areas where multiple ley lines cross or spring forth from, usually in areas of magical significance and intense use of magic such as cities with large mage academies, blue dragon nesting grounds, or ancient Titan installations.

entries.name: Arcane Elemental Familiar
entries: Lesser arcane elementals can sometimes be found in the service of powerful mages, acting as servants and carrying out menial tasks.

entries.name: Familiar
entries: A {@creature lesser arcane elemental|WC5E MoM} can be bound into serving another creature as a familiar, forming a telepathic bond with its willing master. While the two are bonded, the master can sense what the elemental senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other. While the elemental is within 10 feet if its master, the master shares the elemental's Magic Resistance trait. If its master causes it physical harm, the elemental will end its service as a familiar, breaking the telepathic bond.

entries.name: Fel Elemental
entries: On planets devastated by the invasion of demons, the very elements will invariably be poisoned by the cancerous magic of demonkind known as the Fel. Manifesting as a sick green flame that fuels itself with the life force of others, the Fel is the very definition of unnatural. In places where the Fel is exceptionally soaked into the elements, it may take form as a mindless elemental of green flame and extreme aggression, a sinful combination of creation and unmaking given shape.

entries.name: Fel Cores
entries: The infernal core of a Fel elemental is a disgusting thing, something like a pulsing heart of pure corruption. These cores are a vital part of demonic magic, as they are used to power many of their mechanical or magical constructs. Fel forges are fueled by malformed elemental coals, and demon weapons are crafted from ores deeply infused with the Fel.

entries.name: Terror Forming
entries: The corruption of worlds that spawns these parodies of elemental life is a major step in any large-scale invasion by the Burning Legion. Their corruption of the land and poisoning of the air serves many purposes; it helps the demons acclimate, making the place more to their liking, while harming and demoralizing their enemies.

It also benefits the Burning Legion by warping natural resources to suit their needs, creating fel iron ores and brutish, corrupted wildlife that feeds their armies. The end result is a burnt-out, black wasteland colored only by neon green embers and lava, covered by layers of smog so thick that no life may remain.

entries.name: Beasts of Rage
entries: The fel energies that make up these elementals burns away any shred of sapience they might have once possessed, leaving them nearly rabid. This anger fuels their flames, allowing their fires to burn hot enough to singe even true flame elementals. Only the greatest of their number regain any sense of true intellect and even then only in the form of a bestial cunning.

data.name: Constructs
entries: [PH] This sections contains constructs animated by gears or magic.

entries.name: Enchanted
entries: Though made from humble materials — flesh and bones, metal and stone — the creation is a complex process, wrought with magic. At the hands of a skilled creator, their power, durability, and potential is nothing short of astonishing.

These constructs hold no ambition, need no sustenance, feel no pain, and know no remorse. Most are made with a singular purpose in mind; usually as a guardian for a person or a place, or as a construct of war.

entries.name: Blind Obedience
entries: Created to perform their given task, without fault. If left without any new instructions, they will continue to follow its current orders to the best of its abilities. If they are unable to do so, they will either remain idle until new orders are given or break down into a violent rampage. They cannot think or act for themselves. Though they understand their commands perfectly, they have no real grasp of language and cannot be tricked or reasoned with.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: They don't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
{@note List of Enchanted Constructs}

entries.name: Arcane Golem
entries: Arcane golems are hulking constructs, powered by their crystallized arcane core, that are commonly employed as peacekeepers and defenders. Deep grooves are often carved into their outer shell, allowing the energies from their crystal to surge over them in colorful patterns.
They are highly favoured among blood elves, both for their sturdy build and for their magical resilience. In Quel'thalas, they vigilantly patrol the streets within the city and beyond.

entries.name: Mechanized
entries: Mechanical constructs distinguish themselves from organic creatures mainly for their lack of blood, internal organs, and natural instincts. Instead, gears whirr and circuits spark inside these mobile machinations.

Some act only at the behest of whoever holds the remote, while others automatically carry out their given set of pre-configured instructions. Some mechanicals distinguish themselves even further, possessing instructions so meticulously crafted as to resemble genuine intelligence.

As they are wholly driven by the logic of their instructions, mechanical constructs do not possess the ability to give any emotional response: they cannot be charmed, and they certainly cannot be frightened.

entries.name: Titanic Legacy
entries: The origin of Azeroth's great mechanical achievements can be traced back to the titanic Watchers and the ordering of Azeroth. There, the titanic Keeper Mimiron oversaw the creation of a race of diminutive clockwork humanoids -- mechagnomes, forerunners of the gnomes -- as well as a number of other mechanical creations that have since stood the test of time.

entries.name: Gnomish and Goblin Ingenuity
entries: Alongside the legacy of the gnomes, instinctively carrying on the work of their titanic creator, another point of technological innovation across Azeroth has been the artifically enhanced ingenuity of the goblins. Unlike the gnomes, however, goblin creations have a tendency to be remarkably destructive.

The two races lead a contested field of engineering, and have overseen countless mechanical wonders and mishaps across the years -- including cities, transportation systems, explosive automatons, and giant death rays.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: A mechanical creature doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
{@note List of Mechanized Constructs}

entries.name: Mechanical Animal Template
entries: A mechanical animal is any Huge or smaller construct created by a skilled engineer to mimic a beast of the same size. The following characteristics change or are added to a creature when a mechanical version is created.

entries.name: Retained Characteristics
entries: The mechanical animal retains its Armor Class, hit points, Hit Dice, Speed, Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, vulnerabilities, resistances, immunities, and special traits.

entries.name: Lost Characteristics
entries: The mechanical animal loses its original saving throw and skill bonuses, and special sense. It loses any action that isn't Multiattack or a melee weapon attack that deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. If it has an action or a melee weapon attack that deals some other type of damage, it loses the ability to deal damage of that type, unless the damage comes from a piece of equipment, such as a magic item.

entries.name: Type
entries: The mechanical animal's type is construct, and it loses any tags it might have had.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The mechanical animal is unaligned.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: The mechanical animal's ability scores change as follows: Int 3 (-4), Wis 11 (+0), Cha 1 (-5).

entries.name: Senses
entries: The mechanical animal has 60 feet darkvision.

entries.name: Condition Immunities
entries: The mechanical animal can't be charmed, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, or gain exhaustion levels.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The mechanical animal loses all languages it might've known, and understand the languages of its creator, but can't speak.

entries.name: Immutable Form
entries: The mechanical animal is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

entries.name: Sample Mechanical Animal
entries: As an example, the {@creature Mechanostrider|WC5E MoM} shown here uses the base statistics of a {@creature tallstride|WC5E MoM}.

entries.name: Harvest Golem
entries: A lumbering figure skulking across the fields, with razor-sharp claws and blazing, orange eyes: that is the visage of the Harvest Golem. These large, terrifying 'scarecrows' sow terror and wreak havoc across the fallow fields of Westfall. Where they came from or who made them still remains a mystery, but it is clear as day that they have been programmed with a single goal in mind — driving the farmers from the land, killing them if necessary.
Anyone looking to cross Westfall would be wise to stay alert, look out for any odd figures in the distance, and keep clear of the fields after nightfall.

entries.name: Alarm-o-Bot
entries: These constructs are, as the name suggests, walking alarms. Envisioned by gnomes as a safeguard against threats hiding in the dark, rugged terrain of their homeland, the alarm-o-bot keeps a constant watch for sights, sounds, and more with its numerous sensors. If there's a presence it cannot confirm to be friendly, it blares out a high-pitched warning that danger is afoot.

entries.name: Bombling
entries: An old goblin classic, the bombling -- or bomb bot -- is a small set of legs and a pair of eyes designed to carry an explosive charge on its back. It can be primed both to a specific target and to a general swathe of targets, which it will then try to chase down. Once it gets close enough, it detonates.

entries.name: Crowd Pummeler
entries: A mechanical design adopted by both goblins and gnomes, crowd pummelers take the form of a tall, bipedal construct loaded with weapons. Its name is not coincidental, as it is often used as a cheap throw-away sentry; programmable with a set of laws and regulations, alongside a chief directive to pummel any perpetrators.

entries.name: Arcane Nullifier
entries: [PH] An arcane nullifier is a modified crowd pummeler to combat magical enimies of gnomeregan.

entries.name: Mechano-Tank
entries: The Mechano-tank, or spider tank, is a gnomish construct best known for its armoured chassis and spider-like design. Built for close quarters, the tanks are reinforced to withstand the elements and fined-tuned for maximum destruction. Their legs are able to contract and release, allowing the tank to launch forward into combat.

entries.name: Crewing a Mechano-tank
entries: Most mechano-tanks are manual machines that require a pilot to operate, and even autopiloted tanks can be overwritten to work manually for a time.

A creature can use its action to attempt to climb a {@b piloted} mechano-tank by succeeding on a DC 14 Strength (Athletics) check. On a failed save, the creature expends half its movement and is unable to climb the mechano-tank.

The controls of the mechano-tank is sealed tight behind a hatch. The hatch can be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check, or broken if dealt 20 bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, it has an Armor Class (AC 15).

A Small or smaller creature can expend 5 feet of movement to enter an unoccupied mechano-tank. A creature unfamiliar with the controls of tank must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence check to understand the controls of the machine before it is able to pilot it and control its actions and movement.

While piloted, the mechano-tank's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores are exchanged with those of the pilot. A piloted tank uses the initiative of its pilot. The pilot must use its action, reaction, and movement to use the machines action options or force it to move to a new location. While a creature is crewing the mechano-tank, it is considered to have full cover against any attack made against it from the ground.

Taking control of an {@b autopiloted} tank requires a successful DC 17 Tinker's Tool Intelligence check. On a successful save, the creature takes control of the tank until the end of the creature's next turn. At which point the tank's failsafe mechanisms return, requiring a new save to temporarily take control of it.

entries.name: Shredder
entries: Shredders are large mechanical constructs: a marvel of goblin ingenuity, created to truly maximize profits from mass deforestation. The sturdy machines are equipped with a clamping claw and a deadly sawblade, making them just as  efficient lumberjacks as effective combatants when outraged woodland denizens come for revenge.
Shredders are core to numerous goblin enterprises, across Azeroth. They are manual machines, requiring either an operator or an operator's instructions.

entries.name: Enemies of the Forest
entries: The brutally efficient deforestations conducted by shredders have garnered them a deep-seeded hatred among those who dwell in the wilds. Many of whom work tirelessly to push back and sabotage the constructs, if only to save their home.

entries.name: War Constructs
entries: Shredders have on occasion become frontline fighters in times of war. If a goblin on its lonesome won't pose much of a threat, a ruthless goblin operating a spinning buzzer-blade certainly will.

entries.name: Crewing a Shredder
entries: Most shredders are manual machines that require a pilot to operate, and even autopiloted shredders can be overwritten to work manually for a time

A creature can use its action to attempt to climb a {@b piloted} shredder by succeeding on a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check. On a failed save, the creature expends half its movement and is unable to climb the shredder.

A Medium or smaller creature can expend 5 feet of movement to enter an unoccupied shredder. A creature unfamiliar with the controls of shredders must succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence check to understand the controls of the machine before it is able to pilot it and control its actions and movement.

While piloted, the shredder's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores are exchanged with those of the pilot. A piloted shredder uses the initiative of its pilot. The pilot must use its action, reaction, and movement to use the machines action options or force it to move to a new location. While a creature is crewing the shredder, it is considered to have three-quarters cover against any attack made against it from the ground.

Taking control of an {@b autopiloted} shredder requires a successful DC 14 Tinker's Tool Intelligence check. On a successful save, the creature takes control of the shredder until the end of the creature's next turn. At which point the shredder’s  failsafe mechanisms return, requiring a new save to temporarily take control of it.

data.name: The Dead & the Scourge
